misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted problem: computed average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a physics-style average acceleration calculator (using v0, v1, t and (v1 - v0) / t) instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums only the even numbers. This indicates a misunderstanding of the problem requirements, not just a small implementation slip.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads initial velocity v0, final velocity v1, and time t, then compute and print the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user and compute the sum of only the even numbers among those 5 integers, then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompts user with "Enter v0, v1, and t:" instead of asking for 5 integers.
Reads three double values (v0, v1, t) rather than five integers.
Does not use any logic related to checking even numbers (no use of % 2).
Computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints "The average acceleration is" instead of summing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing code from a different assignment about average acceleration or misreading the current problem statement, leading to solving the wrong task entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Design an algorithm specifically for: (1) reading 5 integers, (2) checking each with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, (3) accumulating a running sum of the even numbers, and (4) printing that sum.
related_concepts: Translating problem requirements into code structure
Using the modulus operator to test for even numbers
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variable names, number and type of inputs, and the formula) corresponds to a different problem about average acceleration and does not address any aspect of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: This code clearly shows the student is solving an average acceleration problem (v0, v1, t, (v1 - v0) / t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration (using variables v0, v1, and t) instead of the required program to read 5 integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers among them. The submission bears no relevance to the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program calculating average acceleration based on initial velocity (v0), final velocity (v1), and time (t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 distinct integers, using a loop structure, applying a conditional check (modulus), and accumulating a sum.
symptoms: Program prompts for specific physics variables (v0, v1, t)
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum
Required looping and conditional logic are entirely absent
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or confusion regarding the specific problem assigned (possibly referencing a previous or alternative assignment).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully review the problem statement (Q1: Sum of Even Numbers) and ensure your code addresses all components: reading 5 inputs, using a loop, checking for evenness, and accumulating the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code solves a well-known physics calculation (average acceleration) that has no overlap with the requested task (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The prompt asks for variables related to acceleration, not the 5 generic integers required by the task.

evidence.snippet:
double r=(v1-v0)/t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+r);
evidence.note: The core calculation and output address average acceleration, confirming the student solved the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment. The task requires reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, but the student instead wrote code to calculate average acceleration from physics (reading v0, v1, and t to compute (v1-v0)/t).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is about calculating average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (divisible by 2), and summing only those even numbers. For example: 3 8 2 7 4 → 8+2+4=14.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code performs physics calculation instead of even number summation
Output is 'The average acceleration is [value]' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: [value]'
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either did not read the problem statement carefully or confused this assignment with a different physics-related problem. This represents a fundamental failure to understand the task requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) Read 5 integers in a loop, (2) Check if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) If even, add to a running sum, (4) Print the final sum. Start over with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with no relation to the assigned task (sum of even numbers). This is not a minor mistake but a fundamental misunderstanding of the entire assignment.

evidence.note: The entire program solves a physics problem (average acceleration) instead of the assigned task (sum of even numbers). It reads 3 doubles for a physics formula rather than 5 integers for filtering and summation.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (solving a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration using v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones. This indicates they did not understand or attend to the actual specification of the task.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Reads three double values rather than five integers.
Performs a physics-related calculation (average acceleration) instead of summing even numbers.
No loop or conditional logic related to even-number checking or accumulation.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reused code from a different physics-related assignment (average acceleration) or did not carefully read and interpret the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the program specifically to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) check each for evenness using n % 2 == 0, (3) keep a running sum of even numbers, and (4) print that sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, prompt text, and formula match a standard average-acceleration problem and do not reference summing numbers or evenness at all.

evidence.note: Code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation with three double inputs, not reading 5 integers or summing even numbers as required.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address assignment prompt

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a completely different task (likely Question X: Average Acceleration calculation) and submitted it for this problem (Q1: Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly 5 distinct integer inputs and use a summation logic.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Reads only 3 inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of 5
Inputs are read as doubles instead of integers

misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or complete misinterpretation of the task requirements (submitting code for the wrong problem).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: The program reads only 3 inputs and reads them as doubles (`s.nextDouble()`) instead of reading 5 integers as required by the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student interpreted the input requirement as meaning three double variables (v0, v1, t) relevant to their (wrong) acceleration formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use `s.nextInt()` five times (or within a loop) to satisfy the 'reads 5 integers' requirement.
symptoms: Uses `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`
Only three input variables defined (v0, v1, t)
misconceptions.root_cause: Direct mismatch between required input specification and coded input handling.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you are using the correct Scanner method (`nextInt()`) and that you read the exact number of data points (5) specified by the problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calls `nextDouble()` three times when five `nextInt()` calls are needed.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misunderstanding - Wrong Problem Domain
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (summing even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or misalignment with the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem involving velocity and acceleration rather than a basic program to sum even integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires: (1) Read exactly 5 integers, (2) Identify which are even, (3) Sum the even numbers, (4) Print the sum. The code should follow the pattern in the sample run provided.
symptoms: Input prompts request v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Only 3 inputs are read instead of 5
Output shows acceleration calculation instead of sum of even numbers
No loop or even-number detection logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have submitted code from a different assignment, or failed to carefully read the problem statement and sample run provided.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment: Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers. Review the sample run. Write code with: a loop (e.g., for(int i=0; i<5; i++)), a check (n%2==0), and an accumulator for the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem with a different domain (physics/acceleration vs. number filtering). The input prompts, output format, and all logic are incompatible with the assignment. This is unmistakably the wrong solution.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 variables related to acceleration physics, not 5 integers for even-number summing. Both the input prompt and output format are completely wrong for this assignment.
